title: 113_s2952
content: The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is comprised of 15 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Appointments include individuals with expertise in academic research, data management, confidentiality, privacy, and program administration. Three members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, including 2 academic researchers or data experts, and 1 with expertise in database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. Three members appointed by the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives, including 2 academic researchers or data experts, and 1 with expertise in database management. Three members appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate, including 2 academic researchers or data experts, and 1 with expertise in database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. Three members appointed by the Minority Leader of the Senate, including 2 academic researchers or data experts. Three members appointed by the Minority Leader of the Senate, including 2 academic researchers or data experts, and 1 with expertise in database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. Consideration given to individuals with expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, confidentiality, or database management for appointments. The President selects the chairperson of the Commission and the Speaker of the House. The President selects the chairperson of the Commission and the Speaker of the House selects the co-chairperson. Appointments to the Commission must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the duration of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without pay and travel expenses are covered. Members of the Commission serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses while away from their homes or regular places of business. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and statistical protocols for Federal policymaking. This study aims to integrate administrative data for program evaluation and policy research by qualified researchers. The Commission will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and statistical protocols for Federal policymaking. This study aims to integrate administrative data for program evaluation and policy research by qualified researchers. Recommendations will be made on modifying data infrastructure, incorporating outcomes measurement, and creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data. The Commission will study the integration of administrative data for program evaluation and policy research. This includes identifying relevant administrative datasets, linking them to survey datasets, addressing legal and administrative barriers, determining data-sharing infrastructure, and exploring self-funding options for a potential clearinghouse. The Commission will study data-sharing infrastructure for merging and accessing data, self-funding a clearinghouse, determining access for qualified researchers, setting limitations on data use, protecting privacy, using data for program improvement, and incentivizing interagency data sharing. The Commission will inform program administrators and policymakers on improving program design and incentives for interagency information sharing. Upon approval by three-quarters of the members, the Commission will submit detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations to the President and Congress. The Commission will submit a report with recommendations for legislation or administrative actions within 15 months of a majority of members being appointed. The term "administrative data" refers to information generated or collected by an agency for Federal programs. The Commission will operate and have powers as outlined in Section 5. The heads of various agencies will advise and consult with the Commission on matters within their areas of responsibility, including the Office of Management and Budget, the Bureau of the Census, the Internal Revenue Service, and others. The Commission, consisting of various agencies including the Social Security Administration, Department of Education, Department of Justice, and others, will meet within 30 days of majority member appointment. The chairperson and co-chairperson will establish written rules of procedure, including a quorum requirement. The Commission will establish rules of procedure, including a quorum requirement. It may hold hearings, contract with agencies or persons, and use the United States mails. The Commission may use the United States mails, accept gifts, and contract with the National Academy of Public Administration for administration. Funding is subject to availability of appropriations from principal statistical agencies. The Director of the Census can request up to $2,000,000 from principal statistical agencies for the operations of the Commission. The term "principal statistical agency" is defined in a report by the Office of Management and Budget. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson with the concurrence of the co-chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff and procure temporary services as needed. The Commission may hire individuals for intermittent services at rates not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for a comparable position under the General Schedule. The Commission will terminate within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
